newsitem.title: ALBANIA: Albanian port gives Italy's Prodi hero's welcome.
newsitem.headline: Albanian port gives Italy's Prodi hero's welcome.

text.p: The people of this rebel-held city, waving flags and flowers, gave Italian Prime Minister Romano Prodi a hero's welcome on Sunday and lambasted Albania's elected President Sali Berisha.

Thousands lined the streets of the southern port, scene of much violence since the Balkan state slid into near-anarchy six weeks ago, to hail Prodi before a full-scale deployment of a multinational force in Albania later this week.

Prodi, at the cost of a rift with his hard-left allies, won parliament's approval last week for Italy to lead the 6,000-strong eight-nation mission which will distribute emergency food and aid across Albania.
Nearly 300 people have been killed and about 700 hurt in an armed uprising since the collapse of get-rich-quick investment schemes in which many Albanians lost their life savings.

A high-speed motorcade of heavily-armed Italian marines, Vlore police brandishing Kalashnikov rifles and journalists, overtaking each other in a mad rush to keep up with Prodi, bolted into Vlore to the delight of its cheering residents.

The motorcade had charged from a field beside a salt lake, 10 km (six miles) from Vlore, where Albanian and Italian military helicopter convoys deposited Albanian Prime Minister Bashkim Fino and a few minutes later, Prodi and a few officials.
The landing site was chosen as a security precaution, out of rifle range from the city centre where the protests broke out in February after a local investment scheme collapsed.
Albania is awash with weapons after people ransacked armouries, deserted by soldiers and police during the unrest.
There had been fears of an anti-Italian backlash in Vlore after the sinking of a refugee ship off Italy on March 28.
Tirana says at least 80 people died. Many of the 34 survivors of the boat, which had left Vlore, accused the Italians of ramming the vessel, charges the navy denied.

Two dozen Italian marines in khaki combat gear and dozens of police could not stop a stampede of well-wishers and reporters from forming a scrum around Prodi and Fino, who greeted each other with a kiss on the cheek.

Twenty minutes later, Prodi's unmarked saloon, shielded by his marines on armoured cars mounted with large machine-guns, received a hero's welcome in Vlore, 150 km (90 miles) south of the capital Tirana.
Many people waved red-and-black Albanian flags and purple flowers and held banners reading "Welcome Mr Prodi" and "We Want Our Money Back".

Several were written in Italian and one read: "Down with Berisha mafia", a reference to the president, a northerner blamed by many Albanians for the collapse of the investment schemes in Europe's poorest country.
Rebel-held town councils, called "national salvation committees", took control of most of the south, including Vlore, more than a month ago.
At least 10,000 people gathered outside a university building where Prodi held talks with Fino.
The crowd sang out "Prodi" and clapped, and chanted "Berisha" pointing thumbs down.
At a news conference in a classroom daubed with graffiti in the university building, the head of Vlore's rebel town council, Medin Xhelili, piled the blame on Berisha for the country's woes.
"We are the product of the bad government of the Democratic Party and Berisha," Xhelili said, flanked by Prodi.
The Italian prime minister said he was determined not to get involved in domestic Albanian politics.
Prodi expressed his condolences to Fino over the sinking of the refugee ship and called for a minute's silence.
Xhelili held aloft an Italian flag with Prodi in order to show Vlore's welcome of the Italian presence in the city.
